unnormalised: The year I turned 25, I decided to finally act on my wanderlust. After saving for what felt like an eternity working as a software engineer in Bangalore, I booked a solo trip around Southeast Asia. My meticulously planned itinerary started in Bangkok, Thailand. Before leaving, I converted ₹50,000 to Thai Baht. The exchange rate at Thomas Cook that day was roughly ₹1 to 0.42 THB, leaving me with approx. 21,000 THB to start my adventure.
normalised: The year I turned twenty five, I decided to finally act on my wanderlust. After saving for what felt like an eternity working as a software engineer in Bangalore, I booked a solo trip around Southeast Asia. My meticulously planned itinerary started in Bangkok, Thailand. Before leaving, I converted rupee fifty thousand to Thai Baht. The exchange rate at Thomas Cook that day was roughly rupee one to zero point four two T-H-B, leaving me with approximately twenty one thousand T-H-B to start my adventure.

unnormalised: Bangkok was a sensory overload, in the best way possible. The vibrant street food scene was a constant temptation. Pad Thai from a street vendor cost me about 50 THB. A refreshing mango sticky rice set me back another 80 THB. Initially, I was constantly mentally converting the prices back into rupees, but after a few days, I started to get the hang of it.
normalised: Bangkok was a sensory overload, in the best way possible. The vibrant street food scene was a constant temptation. Pad Thai from a street vendor cost me about fifty T-H-B. A refreshing mango sticky rice set me back another eighty T-H-B. Initially, I was constantly mentally converting the prices back into rupees, but after a few days, I started to get the hang of it.

unnormalised: Next on my list was Singapore. Known for its high cost of living, Singapore was a different beast altogether. I knew my Rupees wouldn’t go far, so I only had a small amount. Converting INR to SGD was an eye-opener. The exchange rate was approximately ₹1 to 0.016 SGD, meaning my remaining Rs. 10000 converted to a mere 160 SGD. Accommodation was a major expense. Hostels were the cheapest option, but even those were around 30 SGD per night. A simple meal at a hawker center could easily cost 10 SGD.
normalised: Next on my list was Singapore. Known for its high cost of living, Singapore was a different beast altogether. I knew my Rupees wouldn’t go far, so I only had a small amount. Converting I-N-R to S-G-D was an eye-opener. The exchange rate was approximately rupee one to zero point zero one six S-G-D, meaning my remaining rupees ten thousand converted to a mere one hundred and sixty S-G-D. Accommodation was a major expense. Hostels were the cheapest option, but even those were around thirty S-G-D per night. A simple meal at a hawker center could easily cost ten S-G-D.

unnormalised: From Singapore, I hopped over to Vietnam. Suddenly, my money felt like it stretched much further. The exchange rate between INR and VND was incredible. Rs. 1000 converted to roughly 300,000 VND! A bowl of Pho from a local eatery was a mere 30,000 VND, and a bia hoi (local beer) was just 5,000 VND. My backpacking budget suddenly felt very generous.
normalised: From Singapore, I hopped over to Vietnam. Suddenly, my money felt like it stretched much further. The exchange rate between I-N-R and V-N-D was incredible. Rupees one thousand converted to roughly three hundred thousand V-N-D! A bowl of Pho from a local eatery was a mere thirty thousand V-N-D, and a bia hoi (local beer) was just five thousand V-N-D. My backpacking budget suddenly felt very generous.

unnormalised: Towards the end of my trip, I had some USD that a relative gifted me, which I had initially thought I wouldn't use, but Southeast Asia gave me a brilliant plan. I wanted to buy some souvenirs, but I was unsure about the best currency to hold for the final leg of my trip. Converting USD to IDR (Indonesian Rupiah) was a shock, as I got 15,000 IDR for 1 USD. I went to a local market, and the prices of souvenirs were unbelievably cheap. This allowed me to buy twice as many gifts!
normalised: Towards the end of my trip, I had some U-S-D that a relative gifted me, which I had initially thought I wouldn't use, but Southeast Asia gave me a brilliant plan. I wanted to buy some souvenirs, but I was unsure about the best currency to hold for the final leg of my trip. Converting U-S-D to I-D-R (Indonesian Rupiah) was a shock, as I got fifteen thousand I-D-R for one U-S-D. I went to a local market, and the prices of souvenirs were unbelievably cheap. This allowed me to buy twice as many gifts!

unnormalised: The trip taught me more than just geography and history; it gave me a crash course in currency conversions and budgeting. I learned to appreciate the relative value of money in different parts of the world and how a little planning and understanding of exchange rates can make a world of difference – literally! I returned to Bangalore with memories, souvenirs, and a newfound appreciation for personal finance and the value of making sure your Rupees go far when travelling!
